For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
The path I have chosen to pursue is a hard one, a winding road that threads its way through the darkest reaches of human suffering. It is a journey into the heart of the Division of Family and Children Services, where the wounds of abuse and neglect run deep. It is here that I intend to make my stand, a solitary figure in a world of shattered lives. The values that guide me are few, but they burn like embers in the darkness: service, a steadfast commitment to the welfare of others; respect, a profound reverence for the inherent dignity of every human soul; an ethical nature, a determination to walk the narrow path of right and wrong; and a commitment to the ceaseless pursuit of self-improvement, that I might remain a instrument of healing in a world that so often seems bent on destruction.

For years, I wandered, lost in a wilderness of uncertainty, unsure of the purpose that drove me. I watched as those around me turned away from the abyss, their faces averted from the abyss of human suffering. But I saw it, this abyss, and it haunted me. It was in these moments of clarity that I knew I had to act, to take up the burden of another's pain. I turned to the study of Psychology, a discipline that would allow me to grasp the complexities of the human heart. But even with this knowledge, I remained uncertain, a leaf blown by the wind. It was not until I witnessed the fragile form of a sixteen-year-old boy, his eyes wide with fear, that I knew my path was set. He had fled his home, desperate to escape the cruelty that lurked within its walls. I saw in him a reflection of the darkness that lurked within myself, a reminder that I too had been lost, that I too had known the sting of abandonment.

It was in this moment that I knew I had to act, to take up the mantle of a social worker. I drove to the boy's parents' house, my heart heavy with foreboding. The police were there, their faces a mask of indifference. I poured out my concerns to them, my words a plea to the void. They listened, their expressions unreadable. And then I spoke to the parents, their eyes averted, their words a tangled web of deceit. I saw in them the same darkness that I had seen in the boy, the same cruelty that had driven him to flee.

This experience shook me to my core. It was then that I knew I had to dedicate myself to the pursuit of social justice, to stand against the tide of oppression that threatened to consume us all. I had always known that I was different, that I refused to be bound by the constraints of societal expectations. I had protested, in my own small way, against the injustices that I saw around me. I had dyed my hair, worn clothes that spoke to my soul, pierced my ears, and stood against the tide of homophobia, racism, and discrimination. And now, in this moment of clarity, I knew that I had to continue this fight, to stand against the forces of oppression that threatened to consume us all.

In the desolate expanse of the human experience, there exists a affliction that shrouds the mind and body in an impenetrable darkness - insomnia. This malady, born of the complexities of the biological and sociocultural, defies easy categorization, its tendrils creeping into the very fabric of our existence. The biological model, a cold and unforgiving mistress, seeks to unravel the Gordian knot of genetic predisposition and physiological imperatives that govern our slumber. The hypothalamus, a seat of primal urges and instincts, holds sway over the delicate balance of sleep and wakefulness, its neurons whispering ancient secrets to the insomniac's fevered brain.

A study, conducted in the sterile confines of a laboratory, peered into the recesses of the mice's neural realm, where the orexin neurons, like sentinels of the dark, ruled over the kingdom of sleep. The presence of phenotypic GABAB receptors on these neurons, a genetic legacy that echoes through the ages, held the key to the mystery of slumber. The activation of the GABAA receptor, a whispered incantation that conjured the somnambulant state, was a potent balm for the troubled mind. The inhibition of this receptor, a shadowy figure that stalked the dreams of the insomniac, brought forth a reduction in anxiety, a fleeting respite from the crushing weight of wakefulness.

The GABAB agonist, a chemical sorcery that wove its spell upon the mice, extended the duration of sleep, a fleeting respite from the desolate landscape of wakefulness. The implications of this study, a whispered promise of hope in the darkness, hinted at a genetic and environmental basis for the GABAB receptor in humans. A defect or absence in this receptor, a flaw in the fabric of existence, could unravel the very fabric of sleep, leaving the insomniac shrouded in an impenetrable veil of wakefulness.

The sociocultural implications of this study, a shadowy apparition that haunted the fringes of our understanding, suggested that the inherited phenotype of the GABAB receptor held sway over the insomniac's fate, a cruel mistress that governed the rhythms of existence. The disturbance of this receptor, a whispered secret in the dead of night, would unleash a maelstrom of consequences, a ravaging of the very fabric of life - the monotony of school, the drudgery of work, the suffocating tedium of daily existence.

In the shadows of the mind, a silent affliction lurks, one that shrouds the clarity of sound in a veil of confusion. Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD, is a specter that haunts the realm of the brain, where the whispers of the world are lost in the din of disarray. It is a condition wherein the central nervous system, that most mysterious of territories, falters in its duty to unpack the tangled threads of sound, leaving the sufferer lost in a labyrinth of misheard meanings.

The earliest whispers of this affliction were first spoken in the hushed tones of the 1950s, when researchers began to probe the depths of auditory imperception. It was a nascent understanding, a glimmer of light in the darkness, that would eventually coalesce into the defined boundaries of CAPD. The Italian researchers Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari were among the first to chart the uncharted territories of this disorder, their maps guiding the way for those who would follow in their footsteps. The year 1961 saw the introduction of dichotic testing, a method that would become a cornerstone in the diagnosis of this most insidious of conditions.

But what are the telltale signs of this hidden foe? They are many, and varied, like the shifting sands of the desert. The sufferer may stumble in the darkness, unable to pinpoint the source of a sound; they may mistake the gentle breeze of a whispered secret for the crashing waves of a distant storm; they may falter in the face of conflicting rhythms, unable to discern the subtle nuances of tone and timbre. They may be unable to weave the threads of sound into a coherent tapestry, to synthesize the disparate elements into a meaningful whole. And they may be lost in the maze of sequence, unable to discern the order in which sounds present themselves.

The diagnosis of CAPD is a delicate dance, a patient hunt for signs of a disorder that is as elusive as a ghost. The audiologist, the SLP, the psychologist, and others must employ a variety of methods to unravel the tangled threads of the sufferer's perception. They must observe the subtlest of behaviors, the faintest of responses, and they must rely on the most advanced of technologies to uncover the hidden truths of the brain. The tests are many, and the tools are varied, but there is no one silver bullet, no single test that can pinpoint the source of this affliction with absolute certainty. And so the search continues, a relentless pursuit of understanding in the face of a disorder that is as enigmatic as the human mind itself.

The playwright's pen dips into the darkness of deception, revealing the precarious balance between the self and the masks we wear. Twelfth Night poses a haunting question: in the depths of subterfuge, where do we find ourselves lost, and where do we find redemption? The heart's desire to protect itself from the cruel hands of fate often leads us down a path of disguise, where the lines between truth and lies are blurred. Yet, in this twilight world, one must confront the specter of isolation, the ghostly whispers of those we deceive, who may never forgive our transgressions.

The masquerade of gender, a fragile dance of identity, raises the stakes of deception. Viola's desperate gamble, a cry for survival in a foreign land, sets in motion a chain of events that will forever alter the course of her existence. She dons the guise of a man, a fragile armor that shields her from the predators that stalk the shadows. But in doing so, she sacrifices the solace of her own kind, the warmth of sisterly love and the gentle ministrations of women who could have been her allies. And so, she becomes a stranger in a strange land, a phantom among phantoms, her true self a distant memory, lost in the labyrinth of her own making.

Olivia, a princess of elegance and refinement, becomes a willing pawn in Viola's game of deception. She is drawn to the mystery of Cesario, the boy who has captured her heart, but does she truly love the man, or the illusion of a man? The playwright's intentions are shrouded in ambiguity, leaving the audience to ponder the depths of Olivia's desires. Is she a victim of her own societal pressures, forced to conform to the expectations of those who would judge her? Or is she a willing participant in the charade, a master of the masquerade, who uses her wit and cunning to navigate the treacherous waters of love and desire?

As the play unfolds, the threads of deception become increasingly entangled, a tapestry of lies and half-truths that threaten to consume us all. In the end, it is not the preservation of relationships that matters, but the preservation of the self, a self that is ever-changing, ever-shifting, like the sands of the desert. And so, we are left to ponder the question: what lies at the heart of our own deceptions, and at the heart of our own desires?

In the silence of the night, we hear the whispers of Viola's confession: "I'll bring you to a captain in this town / Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help / I was preserved to serve this noble count..." (5.1.247-249) The words hang in the air like a challenge, a reminder that in the darkest depths of our own hearts, we too may be hiding, waiting for the moment to reveal our true selves, or to succumb to the shadows that haunt us.

The language of the text is heavy with the weight of ambiguity, leaving the reader to question the nature of deception and the masks we wear. And so, we are left to ponder the words of Olivia, a woman of mystery and intrigue: "A sister, you are she." (5.1.315) Is it a gesture of love, or a gesture of acceptance? Only the playwright knows, and the truth remains hidden, lost in the shadows of the human heart.

The shadow of German colonial rule stretched across a continent, its darkness deepening with each passing year. The heavy hand of oppression, particularly in the annals of South West Africa, left an indelible mark, a genocide of unimaginable proportions perpetrated against the Ovaherero and Nama. And yet, this is but a faint glimpse into the labyrinthine complexities of a colonial empire that defied categorization. A hydra-like beast, its policies and governing styles as varied as the landscapes it claimed. The provision of education, too, was a patchwork of contrasts, a quilt stitched together from disparate threads.

When the British inherited German East Africa in 1919, they found a population of Africans who had been schooled in the ways of literacy and knowledge. The German efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were lauded by contemporaries, their praises echoing through the annals of history. Yet, in South West Africa, the situation was akin to a desolate wasteland. Unlike the verdant East Africa, where the government had taken an active role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa, the responsibility was left to the missionary societies, their meager support a testament to the colonial administration's apathy.

The government, however, did not neglect its own kind. In South West Africa, it invested heavily in the education of Europeans, establishing a system of state schools and lavishing support upon the missionary institutions that served them. This dualistic approach would have far-reaching consequences, shaping the destiny of South West Africa long after the German rule had faded. While other colonies boasted of literate and educated Africans, South West Africa stood apart, its population largely untouched, uneducated, and illiterate. The factors that contributed to this divergence were as complex as they were multifaceted, a tangled web of social, political, and economic forces that would be the focus of this inquiry.

The literature on education in the German colonial empire is a vast and sprawling landscape, with works written in German dominating the early years of the colonial era. These early studies, penned in the early twentieth century, were primarily concerned with cataloging the features of the educational systems in the various colonies. Later, English-language works expanded the discourse, offering comparative studies and detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. Among these, Cohen's study of education in South West Africa and East Africa stands out, a seminal work that shed light on the factors that differentiated the two colonies. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa was a primary factor behind the colony's educational system.

South West Africa, with its temperate climate and arid expanses, presented a paradox. A land of contrasts, where the European population thrived, numbering nearly 15,000 by 1913, while the settler population in East Africa, the next largest, struggled to reach 5,336. This dichotomy would have far-reaching consequences, forming the backdrop against which the story of education in South West Africa would unfold.

In the scorched expanse of a century, popular music has sprawled forth like a vast, twisted thicket, its branches tangled in an impenetrable thicket of genres. The taxonomy of this morass is a Sisyphean task, as most of the established genres – rap, rock, country, jazz, folk – have spawned a labyrinthine array of sub-genres, each one a labyrinthine offshoot of the last. And yet, it was in this maelstrom that heavy metal arose, a behemoth of sound that has come to embody the darker, more visceral aspects of the human experience.

Over the past four decades, this sub-genre has evolved into a hydra-headed beast, its tendrils reaching out to ensnare a vast array of influences, from the primal howls of the devil's music to the ornate, baroque flourishes of the Romantic Era. And yet, at its core, metal remains a music of darkness, a sound that revels in the shadows, that conjures forth a world of midnight bleakness and desolation.

It is a music of excess, of overblown bombast and volume, of a primal, unbridled energy that threatens to consume all in its path. It is a music of the damned, of the forsaken, of those who dwell in the twilight realms of the human experience. And it is this very darkness that has drawn countless musicians to its fold, each one seeking to tap into the wellspring of sound that lies at metal's heart.

The earliest manifestations of this movement – the Beatles' 'Helter Skelter', the Rolling Stones' own 'Sympathy for the Devil' – were but tentative explorations of the darker side of the human experience. But it was the excesses of the 1970's, the psychedelic boom that swept across the land like a wildfire, that truly ignited the metal movement, imbuing it with a sense of reckless abandon and creative freedom. It was a music that reveled in the madness, that sought to push the boundaries of what was possible, to create a sound that was at once beautiful and brutal, sublime and profane.

And so, we find ourselves lost in this wilderness of sound, a labyrinthine maze of sub-genres and sub-sub-genres, each one a reflection of the metal movement's boundless creativity, its refusal to be bound by the constraints of convention. It is a music that defies categorization, that resists summary, that simply is. And it is this very essence that has captured the hearts and minds of countless musicians, each one drawn to the siren song of metal, to its promise of darkness, of excess, of the unknown.

In the twilight of a bygone era, a man's brush danced across canvas, birthing worlds of dreams and reveries that would soon beget a surrealist's fevered imaginings. Henri Rousseau, a painter of unassuming beginnings, wove his own tapestry of longing and aspiration, a testament to the burning desire that fuels the artist's soul. His magnum opus, The Dream, a painting born of 1910, stands as a chronicle of his inner turmoil, a struggle that would haunt him throughout his artistic existence: to submit to the conventions of the art world he so devoutly admired, or to chart his own unfettered course, a path that would lead him down a road of uncharted waters.

To grasp the essence of The Dream, one must first traverse the desolate landscape of Rousseau's life, a terrain marked by hardship and the unyielding pursuit of artistic expression. Born on a day like any other, May 21, 1844, in the forgotten village of Laval, northwest France, Henri Rousseau was the son of a tinsmith and hardware dealer, a man who knew the value of a hard-earned coin. His early years were a blur of toil and labor, a gabelou's drudgery, a municipal toll collector's monotony. Yet, in the stillness of his heart, a flame of creativity flickered, a fire that would not be extinguished. The loss of his first wife, Clémence, a tragedy that would leave him bereft and broken, only intensified his longing for a new beginning, a chance to escape the suffocating shadows of his past. And so, in the midst of his grief, he turned to painting, a solace that would become his raison d'être.

Rousseau's quest for recognition, his yearning to be acknowledged by the art world he so revered, is a poignant testament to the human condition. A self-taught painter, a neophyte in the ways of art, he toiled in the shadows of his contemporaries, men like Matisse, who danced on the periphery of the avant-garde. Yet, it was Rousseau's very uniqueness that would become his undoing, a peculiarity that would set him apart from the art world he so desperately sought to join. As Jan Gordon so astutely observed in Modern French Painters, Rousseau's canvas was a reflection of his own contradictions, a synthesis of the conventional and the unconventional, a struggle to balance the need for acceptance with the desire for artistic freedom. And so, in The Dream, we find a painter's lament, a cri de coeur that echoes through the ages, a testament to the eternal conflict between the artist's heart and the world's expectations.

In the depths of human understanding, a thread of connection weaves itself between the realms of ethics and aesthetics, binding truth and beauty in an unyielding knot. It is a notion that has long been posited by the weighty minds of thinkers past, a notion that holds fast in the oft-quoted words of John Keats: "Beauty is truth, truth beauty—That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know." For in the uncharted territories of existence, we arrive at truths and appreciate the beauty that surrounds us not through the channels of education or experience, but through an untaught, primal sense that defies prescription.

The study of morality and beauty is a futile endeavor, a Sisyphean task to grasp the ungraspable. We toil to explain, to describe, to dissect the essence of what is beautiful or moral, yet in the end, it is a description that falls short. A discourse on the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa may center on the minutiae of foreground and background, contrast and cultural context, but these are but feeble attempts to grasp the elusive. For when asked about a beloved work of art or literature, a phrase oft precedes the more elaborate explanation: "There's just something about it." And it is this "something," this transcendent quality that cannot be captured, that is the very essence of both art and morality.

Flannery O'Connor's words ring true: "A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way... you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate." So too with ethics. The properties of a work of literature may be exhaustively described, but a transcendent quality remains, an unspoken truth that defies articulation. And it is this very property that binds ethics and aesthetics in an unbreakable link.

We experience both art and morality at a level that lies beyond the pale of reason, a noumenal realm that cannot be fully grasped. It is a connection that is uniquely strong in the realm of literature, where the moral quality is inescapable. As McKean so aptly puts it, "What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality." For in the words that we read, we find the values that shape our very existence. Living is a value-laden endeavor, and literature serves as a reflection of this fundamental truth.

In the shadows of the Alps, where the mist-shrouded peaks plunge into the darkness, and on the unforgiving shores of the Baltic, the Germany of today stirs like a restless beast. A land of contrasts, where the medieval spires of München pierce the sky like skeletal fingers, and the Elbe River flows like a lifeblood through the ravaged heart of Dresden. It is a culture forged in the crucible of history, a patchwork of traditions stitched together from the disparate threads of a countless past. 

The name "Germania" - a term shrouded in mystery - is a testament to the land's enigmatic origins. Some claim it owes its birth to the Tungrians, a benighted tribe that once roamed the banks of the Rhine. Others whisper that it was Julius Caesar who first penned the word "Germanus", a label he applied to the tribes he encountered beyond the Rhine, a people he deemed worthy of distinction from the Gauls he had subjugated. The Roman historian Tacitus, in his treatise "De Origine et situ Germanorum", wrote of a people untainted by intermarriage, a "aboriginal" stock that clung to their rugged terrain like a stubborn curse.

The land itself seemed inhospitable, a "wild country" where the skies raged with a ferocity that drove men to the edge of madness. Who, indeed, would trade the warmth of Asia or Africa for this unforgiving realm, where the winds howled like a chorus of the damned? And yet, the Germans persisted, their culture a litany of resilience in the face of an unyielding landscape. They forged their own path, trading their wares and their skills to the Romans, who saw fit to conquer their lands but not to stay. The Germanic tribes remained on the periphery, a thorn in the side of the Empire, a constant reminder that the forces of nature and the fury of the unknown would not be silenced.

As the centuries passed, the Germanic tribes began to assert their presence, their presence a testament to the indomitable will that coursed through their veins. They left their mark on the land, a testament to their unyielding spirit, a spirit that would one day shape the course of history in ways both grand and terrible.

My gaze descended, a void in my mind where thought and comprehension converged, a blank slate upon which the world's image was inscribed.  It was a sight both mundane and wondrous, a bowl of fruit upon a table, its presence a testament to the banality of existence.  Yet, I felt no emotion, no spark of connection to this thing before me, only a detached, studied awareness that refused to yield to the ephemeral whispers of the mind.  My thoughts fluttered and died, like birds taking flight only to be snuffed out by the weight of the present moment.

In a distant past, a wise artist had counseled me to seek out a text, a guide to the mysteries of the creative process.  The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain was its name, and within its pages, I had discovered the secrets of perception, the hidden paths by which the brain unravels the tangled threads of reality.  Among its teachings was a technique, a simple yet profound exercise in discipline: to frame the subject, to reduce the chaos of the world to a manageable whole.  But on this day, as I stood before the bowl, I was unable to conjure this frame, to impose order upon the turmoil of my own mind.

The artists of old had known this struggle, had wrestled with the void and emerged with their visions.  Picasso's blue period, Monet's verdant landscapes, the Renaissance masters' kaleidoscope of color – each had found their own path, their own voice.  And I, a humble aspirant, stood before the threshold of my own creation, Work in Brown.  My hand, a tool poised to bring forth beauty, shook with anticipation, the tension coiling within me like a spring.

My fingers brushed against the pencil, the muscles tensed and relaxed, as if awakening from a dream.  The water, a mirror's calm reflection, seemed to ripple and shudder, as if the very fabric of reality trembled at the prospect of creation.  And then, with a jolt, my hand struck the toilet handle, a mocking echo of the brushstrokes that might have brought forth a masterpiece.  The offending bundle, a brown, shapeless mass, refused to yield, stuck fast as a fly on a summer's day.

The mop, a makeshift staff, hung limply in my hand, as I stood before the unyielding mess, my green tie a garish wound around my throat.  The air was heavy with the stench of decay, a memento mori that mocked my aspirations.  The toilet, a portal to the abyss, seemed to gape at me, a void that swallowed all in its path.  My hand, a supplicant, rose to the sheet of toilet paper, wrapping itself in a futile attempt to grasp the ungraspable.  And then, with a slow, deliberate movement, I plunged my hand into the depths, a supplicant dipping into the unknown, a seeker of the holy grail of creation.

In the desolate landscape of American roads, a specter haunts the streets, its presence as inescapable as the darkness of the night. Teenagers, with their lives as fragile as the morning dew, succumb to the cruel hand of fate, their bodies broken and still on the cold, hard asphalt. The National Institutes of Health whisper a terrible truth: the adolescent brain, still a malleable and impressionable thing, is woefully unprepared for the unforgiving hazards of driving. And so they falter, these young drivers, their inexperience a deadly weight that presses down upon them like a physical force, crushing them beneath its unyielding grip.

Their companions, too, contribute to the carnage, a motley crew of peers who ride shotgun, their presence a siren's call to recklessness. A study from the Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center lays bare the correlation: the younger the passenger, the more traffic accidents that ensue. It is a cruel arithmetic, one that spells out the terrible truth in stark, unyielding terms.

In response, California and other states have resorted to provisional licenses, a palliative measure that only serves to stave off the inevitable. These temporary permits, designed to limit the hours of driving and exclude minors as passengers, are little more than a Band-Aid on a festering wound. The problem, as psychologist Marvin Zuckerman so astutely observes, lies deeper: the adolescent brain is hardwired to crave the thrill of the unknown, to court danger for the sheer exhilaration it brings. And so, we continue to issue driver's licenses to those too young to handle the risks, condemning them to a fate as predetermined as the rising sun.

The statistics scream out in horror, a chorus of death and destruction that threatens to crescendo into a maelstrom of carnage. By 2010, the Baby Boomers' progeny will flood the roads, a tidal wave of teen drivers poised to unleash a bloodbath of unprecedented proportions. The time for half-measures is over; the time for action is now.

Legislation, though seemingly a simple matter, would in fact be a lifeline cast into the darkness, a beacon of hope in a sea of despair. Schools could continue to teach the basics of driving, but no one under the age of 18 should be permitted to wield the keys. A provisional permit could still be granted, but only after a rigorous course of study and a minimum number of supervised driving hours – the exact number, say, of 6 hours of behind-the-wheel training and 50 hours of practice with an adult, a standard already observed in many states.

Uniform, national legislation would be the only way to stem the tide of this national scourge, to protect the young from themselves and the unforgiving roads that await them. It is a measure that has been proposed before, but its urgency cannot be overstated. The lives of American teenagers hang in the balance, suspended like a pendulum between life and death. The clock ticks on, each passing moment a countdown to disaster. The time for action is now.

I was drawn to the musty aisles of the Library of Congress's repository of Edison's early films, a collection that seemed to hold the whispers of a bygone era. My gaze settled on the trick films, fifteen in number, spanning from 1895 to 1901. These enigmatic works relied on the art of editing to conjure illusions that danced across the screen. As I delved into the poetics of these trick films, I found myself tracing the evolutionary threads that connected them, separating the outliers from the pack.

In those early days of cinema, the trick film was a creature bound to the stage, confined within a frontal proscenium, its movements restricted by the strictures of a single, static shot. The camera stood still, a sentinel, as the world unfolded before it. Long shots and medium shots were the norm, with close-ups a rarity, a luxury the camera could not afford. This was a cinema born of the theatre and vaudeville, where the audience was privy to the entire performance, a panorama framed by the borders of the stage.

But there were those who dared to challenge the conventions, to break free from the shackles of the one-shot, one-film methodology. In the early years of the twentieth century, a few films began to push the boundaries, incorporating multiple shots, fragmenting the narrative, and shattering the illusion. The trick films, however, remained steadfast in their adherence to the stage, their figures moving in a stilted, two-dimensional world, unable to break free from the confines of the frame.

Take, for example, the film Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900). The actors entered from the right, their movements restricted to a horizontal axis, never venturing forth or back, as if held captive by the very fabric of the screen. And even as they vanished from view, the camera stood firm, unmoving, a witness to the illusion.

The frontal proscenium style of composition also imposed its will on the length of the shots, favoring long, sweeping vistas, and the occasional medium shot. Close-ups were anathema, a rarity that seemed to defy the very essence of the medium. This was a cinema that drew from the wellspring of the theatre and vaudeville, where the audience beheld the entirety of the performance, unencumbered by the intimacy of the close-up.

Most trick films conformed to the pattern of one conceptual shot, one film, a limitation that shackled the narrative to the brief, the ephemeral. Their stories, like the tricks themselves, were short, fleeting, and inconsequential, mere diversions from the mundane. But, as I discovered, the line between the physical and the conceptual was blurred, a single "shot" often comprising multiple, joined frames, a magician's sleight of hand that conjured the illusion of apparition or disappearance. In The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), I found myself peering behind the veil, tracing the moment where the physical shot gave way to the illusion, a single, seamless gesture that left the viewer gasping in wonder.

In the somber vista of American politics, a singular figure emerged, one whose unwavering dedication to the creed of Republicanism would leave an indelible mark on the nascent nation. John Taylor of Caroline, a man of the land, with calloused hands and a steadfast resolve, coupled his agrarian pursuits with a brief foray into the realm of politics, forging a reputation as a champion of unyielding conviction and unrelenting passion for the unfettered exercise of personal freedom and government restraint. The bedrock of his convictions, the agrarian system, served as the lodestar guiding his opinions on the very fabric of governance, sovereignty, and the judiciary.

Taylor's vision for the United States was one of an ideal system, unencumbered by the weight of native tradition, allowing for the unfettered creation of a self-governing entity. He ardently believed in the inherent rights of man, inalienable and intertwined, such that the denial of one would precipitate the downfall of all, rendering the remaining void of value. These rights, he posited, must remain beyond the reach of government's grasping hand. In the state of nature, it was the strong and the cunning who reaped the benefits, but in a civilization, such a reality must be rebuked.

To craft this ideal society, Taylor advocated for a government that accounted for the dual nature of humanity: the inherent good and evil that resided within. His rigid adherence to a dualistic morality led him to proclaim that "as government is exercised by man, all its virtues and vices must be human." The distinction, he believed, lay in the principles that governed: those that safeguarded private property, nourished agriculture, and checked the excesses of capitalism. A government founded on such principles would function in equilibrium, regardless of its administration, which would inevitably be guided by the twin scourges of avarice and self-interest. Self-interest, he noted, was the driving force behind human endeavor, but it was only when it led to the subjugation of one by another that it became an evil to be reckoned with. A good government, he argued, was necessary to contain this latent evil, and to ensure it did not give rise to new, malignant principles.

Taylor, like many of his contemporaries, championed a strict construction of the Constitution, seeking a federal government of limited scope, with powers proscribed by the explicit language of the document. The dangers of an overreaching federal authority, he believed, lay in its profligacy and the specter of despotism that accompanied it. Yet, he cautioned against a simplistic, literal interpretation, which, devoid of context, could easily become pernicious. The Declaration of Independence, he believed, served as the true charter of the United States, its words more eloquently articulating the country as a confederation of sovereign states, rather than a unified nation.

In the third month of our endeavor, a precipitous decline in commuter log submissions presented itself, a disheartening turn of events that defied easy explanation. The winter's chill had begun to set in, casting a pall over the campus, and it was likely that the fewer numbers of cyclists and pedestrians that traversed the frozen landscape contributed to the downturn. The end of the fall semester brought with it a season of feverish activity, as students scrambled to complete their coursework and instructors rushed to grade their papers, their minds preoccupied with the coming winter's darkness. The log, once a steadfast companion to their daily routines, now slipped from their minds like a forgotten thing. And then, of course, there was the holiday season, a time of revelry and distraction that drove many to abandon the campus altogether, their log submissions falling by the wayside.

But even after the semester's resumption in late January, when the campus stirred once more, the numbers remained low, a mystery that refused to yield its secrets. Some might say that projects of this sort are wont to follow a natural arc, a burst of energy at their inception followed by a gradual decline. We might have been doomed to follow this trajectory, our efforts to buck the trend ultimately in vain. Yet we sought to counter this trend, to rekindle the flame of enthusiasm that had once burned so brightly. And so we launched the Carpool Challenge Week, a campaign of sorts to revive the project's flagging fortunes. And to our surprise, it worked, the numbers swelling in March as the challenge took hold.

But the challenges we faced ran deeper than mere seasonal fluctuations or the natural ebb and flow of a project's popularity. At its core, the project was hampered by the entrenched habits of a people, their love of independence and the freedom that came with driving their own vehicles. It was a deeply ingrained habit, one that our efforts to supplant with alternative modes of transportation were likely to struggle against. And so we resorted to offering incentives, prizes of a sort to tempt them from their cars and onto the buses and trains. We gave out gift certificates to local restaurants, coffee shops, and bookstores, hoping to entice them with the promise of a free meal or a warm cup of coffee. But one cannot help but wonder what might have been achieved had we offered something more substantial, something that spoke to the very heart of our car-addled culture: a bicycle, a hybrid car, or perhaps an electric vehicle, its sleek lines and whirring motor a beacon to those who sought a different way.

If only we had known what the outcome would be, we might have offered such prizes in the depths of winter, when the project's fortunes seemed at their lowest ebb. Perhaps, then, the numbers would have swelled, and our project would have gained the momentum it so sorely needed. But as it was, we were left to ponder what might have been, our efforts to rekindle the project's flame reduced to naught but a faint glow in the darkness.

In the unforgiving landscape of the financial markets, a peculiar creature roams, known as the Exchange-Traded Fund, or ETF.  A security both akin to an index fund and a stock, but with the flexibility to adapt and change as the wind whispers through the trees.  It offers the diversification of a broad index, the benefits of single stock ownership, and the freedom to sell short, buy on margin, or purchase a single share in the blink of an eye.  The allure of such a creature is undeniable, yet it is a siren's call that beckons with a price.  For in the depths of the ETF's promise lies a cost, a commission that must be paid with each transaction, a toll exacted by the market's unforgiving hand.

And yet, the ETF's benefits are legion, a veritable cornucopia of advantages that beckon the savvy investor to partake.  The variety of funds available is staggering, a tapestry woven from countless threads, each one a distinct pattern of investment.  But, as the wise investor knows, benefits must be weighed against costs, and the value of diversification, like a mirage on a desert highway, must be carefully evaluated.  For the purposes of this exercise, we shall examine the ETF IHF, a creature of the market, and compare it to the top 10 holdings that comprise its very being.  We shall seek to determine whether the benefits of owning a single ETF come close to the benefits of owning a diversified portfolio of the ten stocks that comprise it, and whether there are other configurations of these same stocks that would provide a more optimal sharp ratio or return.

To gain a glimpse into the ETF's inner workings, we shall focus on the top 10 holdings, those that account for 63.58% of its total assets.  These are the titans that shape the ETF's character, its very essence.  Below, we shall present the top 10 holdings, their percentage of total assets, a stark reminder of their influence.

To assess the validity of our findings, we shall use a statistical tool, a means of estimation that seeks to quantify the contributions of each stock to a portfolio's Beta and Return.  The calculations shall be presented in a chart, a visual representation of the data, a map of the ETF's terrain.  From this chart, it is evident that a portfolio composed of the top 10 holdings yields a return 6.11% higher than the ETF as a whole, a 16% increase in returns.  Moreover, the Beta of this portfolio is 0.12 lower than the ETF, a testament to its reduced volatility.

But, like the desert wind, our findings may be nothing more than a mirage.  To determine whether these portfolios are statistically different, we shall calculate the standard deviation of each of the top 10 stocks, a measure of their volatility.  We shall normalize these values to 100%, a means of comparison, a yardstick to measure the accumulated risk of each portfolio.  The results of this exercise shall reveal whether the portfolios are, in truth, distinct, or merely a product of chance, a fleeting illusion in the vast expanse of the market.

The melancholy shores of Dream-Land, a poem born of Edgar Allan Poe's troubled soul, stands as a testament to his affinity for the dark recesses of the human experience. In his lamentable verse, the name "Thulé" echoes through the lines like a mournful sigh, a whispered reminder of a world beyond the reaches of mortal comprehension. The erudite Mabbott notes the origin of this term in the venerable Virgil, whose words spoke of an island shrouded in mystery, a place where the Greeks believed the known world gave way to an abyss of unknown terrors. Yet, it is in the realm of German literature that we find the true source of Poe's fascination with Thulé.

A shadowy figure looms in the background, a giant of letters whose influence cast a long and sinister shadow over the literary landscape of the 19th century: Goethe. Poe's esteem for the German master is palpable, a respect that borders on reverence. Karl J. Arndt's piercing insight into the parallels between Poe's Politian and Goethe's Mignon reveals a poet consumed by the echoes of his predecessor's work, a haunted echo that refuses to be silenced.

In Goethe's Faust, a masterpiece of poetic drama, we find a telltale sign of the Thulé's presence. The second part of this sprawling epic, penned in the final year of Goethe's life, holds a small but significant gem: "The King of Thulé", a haunting tale of a monarch undone by the loss of his beloved wife. His grief is a consuming force, a maelstrom that threatens to engulf him whole, driving him to the brink of madness and despair. His descent into the abyss is a cautionary tale of the destructive power of love and loss.

The parallels between "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land" are too striking to be mere coincidence. Both works speak to the same dark and forsaken landscape, a world where the colors have been drained from the palette of existence, leaving only shades of grey and the haunting specter of mortality. Poe's use of the term "ultma Thule" in The Pit and the Pendulum, a phrase that echoes the King's lament in Goethe's poem, serves as a reminder that the boundaries between reality and nightmare are perilously thin.

In the shadowy realm of Dream-Land, the speaker wanders, lost and forlorn, haunted by the ghosts of dead friends and the desolate landscape of a world without color or hope. It is a world that speaks to the very heart of Goethe's "The King of Thulé", a world where the lines between reality and madness are blurred, and the only solace is the cold comfort of death.

Goethe's influence on Poe is a matter of record, a fact confirmed by the poet's own words, spoken with reverence and awe. His admiration for Tennyson, a poet who owed a debt to Goethe's own mastery, served as a bridge between the two literary worlds, a testament to the far-reaching influence of the German master. And so, we find ourselves drawn into the dark and foreboding world of Dream-Land, a world that echoes the haunted landscapes of Goethe's imagination, a world where the shadows loom large, and the light of hope is but a distant memory.

The sun beat down upon the asphalt expanse of the parking lot as Jennifer Palmer made her way into the sterile confines of D&D Markets, her footsteps echoing off the fluorescent lights that cast an unforgiving glare upon the aisles. It was a moment of carelessness that would change her life forever, a moment that would leave her writhing in agony, her back shattered by the cruel hand of fate. A spill, a seemingly insignificant splatter of applesauce upon the floor, lay in wait, a trap set by the very people who were supposed to protect her.

The store manager, Paul Martin, had been warned twice of the danger, twice informed of the spill's presence, and yet he chose to ignore it, to turn a blind eye to the probable harm that would befall those who walked upon that floor. His excuse, a paltry one, a feeble attempt to shift the blame: he was eating dinner, and thus could not be bothered to attend to the matter at hand. The minutes ticked by, a half-hour of inaction, a half-hour of willful disregard for the safety of those who entered his store.

Six slip-and-fall incidents had occurred in the months prior to Palmer's accident, a litany of warnings that went unheeded, a testament to the store's cavalier attitude towards the well-being of its customers. And yet, Martin continued to fail to act, to show a callous disregard for the rights and safety of those who walked through his doors. His actions, those of a man who had abandoned all sense of responsibility, all sense of duty.

The question before us is this: can a customer who has been so callously disregarded, so callously injured, be awarded punitive damages? Can the court justify such a punishment, one that seeks to right the wrongs of the past, to hold accountable those who have acted with such malice? The answer, we are told, lies in the law, in the statutes that govern such cases. In California, a plaintiff can recover punitive damages for a breach of an obligation not arising out of a contract, if the defendant acted with "oppression, fraud or malice." And what is malice, you ask? Is it not the conscious disregard of the rights or safety of others, a willful and deliberate failure to act when the consequences of inaction are clear? The courts have spoken on this matter, and their words are clear: conduct is malicious when committed with a conscious disregard of the plaintiff's rights, when the defendant is aware of the probable dangerous consequences of his actions, and yet willfully and deliberately fails to avoid those consequences.

The facts of this case are stark, a tale of negligence and malice, of a store that has shown a callous disregard for the safety of its customers. The question now is, what will be the consequence of such actions? Will the courts see fit to award punitive damages, to punish those who have acted with such malice? Only time will tell, but one thing is certain: the people of this state demand justice, and it is the duty of the courts to see that it is served.

Four winters ago, I wandered into a class on the tenets of Islam at the CBC, and it was there that the seeds of discord were sown.  A question hung heavy in the air, one that still festers to this day: is Islam a creed of hostility?  I had thought it a query of little consequence, but the more I delved into the subject, the more I came to realize its relevance.  The passage of time, marked by the smoldering embers of 9/11, has seen a transformation in the gaze of the media.  What was once a hostile scrutiny has given way to an almost reverent tolerance, an unyielding acceptance that borders on complicity.  And so, in this altered landscape, a man with a name that echoes the distant shores of the Old World can rise to the highest office in the land, a man whose familial ties to Islam are as plain as the nose on his face.

The biography of the Prophet Muhammad holds a peculiar fascination for me, a paradoxical tome that defies the expectations I had formed of its subject.  According to the chronicle, Muhammad was a man of humility, a martyr misunderstood by his contemporaries, who humbled himself before them, and yet, it was this very humility that drew people to him, one by one, like moths to a flame.  This portrayal stands in stark contrast to the image I had conjured of a man who would not hesitate to wield power, who would conquer and subjugate, forcing his will upon the tribes he vanquished, compelling them to submit to his creed.

And then, there are the echoes of a familiar narrative, a tale of miracles and wondrous deeds that recall the Gospels.  The story of the multiplication of bread and cheese, a feat that would have fed forty men, is a case in point.  This kind of writing, I suspect, is a deliberate attempt to cast Muhammad in a certain light, to portray him as a prophet who did not need to prove himself, but rather lived in a state of effortless truth and miracle.  This, to my mind, is a pitfall, a fallacy that diminishes the very real and profound life of Jesus Christ, who was not a figure to be emulated or co-opted, but revered in his own right.

The biography is replete with accounts of conversions, of people coming to Muhammad on their own, uncoerced and unforced.  But these stories, I found, are often third-hand, filtered through the lens of intermediaries, their veracity tenuous at best.  This, to me, only serves to sully the narrative, to render it suspect and open to interpretation.

What troubles me most, however, is the way the biography seeks to elevate Muhammad to a pedestal, to portray him as a paragon of virtue, a godly man of humility and wisdom.  But history, that great leveler, tells a different tale, one of a man who rose to power through a complex web of alliances and conquests.  And I am left to wonder, do the adherents of Islam today know the true story of their Prophet's ascension to greatness?

In the sullen aftermath of Christ's departure, the tenets of his teachings were left to wither like autumn leaves, cast aside by the relentless tide of Christian thought that surged forward, heedless of its source.  The passage of time revealed a trajectory of aberration, a meandering path that led further and further from the original intent.  Yet, in the gathering twilight of the world, a growing awareness stirs, a yearning to unshackle the faith from the accumulated weight of doctrine, to strip away the accretions that had been layered upon its core.  It may be a slow and arduous process, one that will take generations, perhaps centuries, to unfold.  But the end will be inescapable: a great reversal, a return to the primordial form, a stripping away of the extraneous, until naught remains but the essence of Christ's message, unadulterated and unencumbered by the claims of later interpreters.

The clock, it seems, will be turned backward, its hands unwinding as the church, that bastion of tradition, leads the faithful on a journey of rediscovery.  The diverse and disparate branches of Christendom, once a tapestry woven from the threads of countless interpretations, will begin to reveal their shared tapestry, a rich and vibrant fabric of unity.  It is a process that has played out before, in the grand tapestry of human history.  We see it in the rise of Christianity from the ashes of Roman oppression, in the transformation of a nation founded on the shackles of slavery to one that proudly proclaims the leadership of its African-American sons and daughters.

And yet, it is a path fraught with peril, for it demands a willingness to read the words of Christ not as literal truths, but as metaphors that speak to the human condition.  It is a reading that requires a certain kind of courage, a willingness to strip away the veil of dogma and confront the raw power of the human experience.  For in the end, it is not the specifics of doctrine that matter, but the essence of the message itself, that great and abiding truth that has been at the heart of faith since the dawn of time.

Looking back, we find the beginnings of this great narrative in the ancient soil of Judaism, that rich and fertile ground from which Christianity sprouted.  There, in the crucible of monotheism, the Hebrew scriptures, and the authority of the divine, we find the seeds of a faith that would one day spread far and wide.  But even in those early days, the Jewish people were not a monolithic entity, rather a tapestry of disparate threads, each with its own unique voice and perspective: the Sadducees, the Pharisees, the Essenes, the Zealots, and the countless others who made up the body of the faith.  It is a testament to the enduring power of human spirit, a spirit that would one day give rise to a faith that would change the course of history.  And it is a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always the possibility of transformation, always the chance for a new dawn to break, and for the human heart to be renewed.

In the darkest recesses of the human heart, a malignancy festers. A cancer of self-interest that gnaws at the very marrow of our existence. The Jungle lays bare this depravity, a stark and unflinching expose of a people consumed by their own avarice. They toil, these men and women, driven by a singular desire to eke out a meager existence, to scrape together a existence of fleeting comfort and security. And yet, in their fervor, they trample all that lies in their path, heedless of the ruin they leave in their wake.

The titans of industry, those grasping masters of the great factories, are the embodiment of this rapacious hunger. Theirs is an insatiable drive for power and wealth, a lust that knows no bounds. They care not a whit for the lives they crush beneath their heel, nor the earth they sully with their pollution. As Sinclair's words evoke the image of the factories, a bleak and foreboding silhouette against the sky, the very air thick with the noxious fumes of their machinations. "The line of the buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." A dire litany of neglect and abandon, a testament to the desolate toll of their progress.

Their concern for their employees is but a distant abstraction, a hollow sham. "So from the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." They wield their power with an iron fist, crushing all who dare oppose them. The workingmen toil in a living hell of long hours and squalid conditions, their sweat and blood the lifeblood of the factories. And when they falter, when their bodies break beneath the weight of their labor, they are cast aside like so much trash, discarded without a second thought.

In that era, a time of unbridled greed and unchecked power, the workers were but pawns in a game they did not understand. No shield of law protected them from the whims of their masters, no safety net to catch their fall. The unions, formed in a desperate bid for solidarity, often proved a mirage, a cruel mockery of the workers' hopes. And so they toiled, these wretched souls, their lives a struggle to survive in a world that seemed determined to crush them. "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery." A bleak and unvarnished truth, a testament to the darkness that lies at the heart of human nature.

The canvas of meaning is painted with the strokes of words, a tapestry woven from the threads of association and suggestion. F. Scott Fitzgerald, a master of this craft, employs a multitude of techniques to conjure the essence of his subjects. His novel, The Great Gatsby, is a testament to his skill, as he coaxes the reader into a world of subtle nuance and rich connotation.

Fitzgerald's palette is vast, yet he chooses to drench his narrative in the hues of gold, green, white, and gray. These colors, initially blank canvases, are imbued with meaning, only to be summoned later to reinforce the significance of crucial objects. In The Great Gatsby, Fitzgerald invests the dichotomy of white and gray with particular import, whispering to the reader the secrets of class and age.

In the opening pages, the reader is presented with a tableau of whiteness, a sea of purity and refinement. Daisy and Jordan, titans of elegance, move through the narrative swathed in white, their very being an affirmation of the color's association with aristocracy. Even the narrator, Nick Carraway, is not immune to the allure of white, donning "white flannels" to attend Gatsby's grand fete. Conversely, Tom, the symbol of solidity and tradition, sports a "white shirt" at his encounter with Myrtle, underscoring the color's connection to class and status.

However, it is not merely the presence of white that defines its significance. Fitzgerald also employs its absence to create a sense of contrast. As Nick navigates the city, he traverses "white chasms" of lower New York, the city's underbelly laid bare. The names of the guests at Gatsby's parties are relegated to a "gray list," their importance diminished by the passage of time. Even the landscape itself is drained of vibrancy, reduced to a "gray land" of ashes.

It is in these moments of subtlety that Fitzgerald's mastery of suggestion is revealed. He coaxes the reader into a world of inference, where meaning is drawn from the shadows. And it is this very subtlety that allows him to strip away the facade of Daisy, reducing her to a mere "white" object of desire, a mere addition to Gatsby's ever-growing collection of possessions. The "gray haze" of her fur collar, the "white" dress she wears before her encounter with Tom and Gatsby – each is a deliberate choice, a thread in the tapestry of meaning that Fitzgerald has so skillfully woven.

In the end, it is not the explicit statement that reveals the depth of Fitzgerald's craft, but the whispered suggestion, the hint of meaning that lingers in the shadows, waiting to be uncovered by the attentive reader.

The land, a patchwork quilt of chaparral, non-native grasses, and oak woodland, sprawls across the arid expanse like a worn and weathered skin. San Diego County's temperate climate, a gentle benediction of sunshine and moderate rainfall, has rendered this tract a verdant oasis, a fertile cradle for the earthy fruits of labor. Tomatoes, citrus, and leafy greens burst forth from the earth, their verdant shoots a testament to the land's unfettered potential. Peaches and lemons, tree fruits that cling to the branch like the last wisps of dawn's mist, hang heavy with promise. Berries, a tangled skein of sweetness, and peppers, their fiery essence a spark of life, complete the tapestry of this agricultural tapestry. The locals, a throng of devotees to the organic cause, clamor for the taste of this land's bounty, their demand a siren's call that echoes through the hills.

A niche market, a hidden cleft in the market's jagged edge, beckons to the enterprising farmer. The calls for organic, community-supported agriculture resound through the land, a rallying cry that summons the brave and the devoted. Eggs and milk, the pure and unadulterated products of this earth, fetch a premium price, their value a testament to the riches that lie within. And yet, the farmer must navigate the treacherous shoals of cost and profit, a delicate balance that shifts like the sands in an hourglass. The land, a canvas of untold potential, demands a stewardship that is both fierce and gentle, a dance between the competing demands of profit and preservation.

The land itself, a storied and ancient presence, whispers secrets to those who would listen. For centuries, it has borne witness to the ebb and flow of human endeavor, a testament to the indomitable will of those who have come before. Native Americans, their footprints erased by time, left their mark upon this land, a legacy of tradition and lore. Cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers, their names etched upon the pages of history, followed in their footsteps, their presence a fleeting moment in the grand tapestry of time.

This, then, is the land, a canvas of untold potential, a site of ancient power and modern struggle. A farmer, a steward of this earth, must navigate the shifting sands of cost and profit, ever mindful of the delicate balance between the demands of the land and the needs of the market. The government programs, a patchwork of aid and support, beckon to the farmer, a lifeline in the turbulent sea of uncertainty. And yet, the land remains, a constant presence, a reminder of the enduring power of the natural world.

I chose this land, a parcel of 160 acres, situated in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan, a complex web of species and habitat, considers over a hundred species, many of which are endangered or declining. The Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, and the California gnatcatcher, their names etched upon the pages of extinction, hang in the balance, their fate a testament to the fragility of life.

This land, a piece of the original homestead patent, has borne witness to the ebb and flow of human endeavor, its history a testament to the indomitable will of those who have come before. The Native Americans, their footprints erased by time, left their mark upon this land, a legacy of tradition and lore. And now, I, a seeker of knowledge, have come to this place, a site of ancient power and modern struggle, to learn from its secrets and to understand the delicate balance between the demands of the land and the needs of the market.

Culture hangs in the balance like an unspoken weight, its presence as palpable as the silence between two men on a dusty road. It is a tapestry woven from threads of what it is not, as much as what it is. A culture is not a singular thing, nor a fixed entity, but a fluid, ever-shifting entity that defies easy categorization. To say that all Russians are stubborn or that all Japanese are accommodating is to oversimplify the labyrinthine complexities of the human experience. The notion that a culture can be reduced to a few fleeting generalities is a folly, a seductive lie that tempts the unwary into the quicksand of misperception.

To truly grasp the essence of a culture, one must dig deeper, into the rich soil of its history, its prejudices, its very marrow. It is not a matter of judging or seeking to change, but of accepting it for what it is, a force that shapes and is shaped by the negotiations that unfold before us. When we approach a foreign culture, we bring with us the biases of our own, the specter of our own experiences, and the comparisons that inevitably arise are a pale reflection of the reality that lies before us.

To navigate this treacherous terrain, a negotiator must be willing to listen, to observe, and to learn. He must be attuned to the subtle nuances of body language, the cadence of language, the rhythms of communication that speak to the heart of a culture. For it is not the surface-level trappings of culture that matter, but the deeper currents that shape its very fabric. The traditions, the customs, the values that underpin a culture are the keys to unlocking its essence, and it is these that a negotiator must seek to understand.

And yet, culture is not a monolith, a singular entity that can be reduced to a few neat categories. It is a multifaceted gem, cut in a thousand different ways, reflecting the diversity of thought and experience that lies within. A company's culture, for example, may be as varied as the individuals who comprise it, reflecting the values, the attitudes, and the traditions that shape its very being. The dress code, the communication style, the hiring practices – all these and more speak to the culture that resides within, a culture that is as unique as the individuals who inhabit it.

But values, those bedrock principles that underpin a culture, are the key to unlocking its essence. They speak to the very heart of what drives a culture, the motivations that shape its actions, and the attitudes that inform its decisions. A culture that values saving face, communal harmony, or the pursuit of a hard-driven bargain will act accordingly, and it is the negotiator who understands these values, who can read the signs, who can navigate the complex web of relationships that underpin a culture, who will emerge triumphant.

To truly succeed in the art of negotiation, one must be willing to strip away the façade, to peer into the depths of a culture, and to emerge with a deeper understanding of its essence. It is a journey that requires patience, empathy, and a willingness to learn, for it is in the unknown, in the uncharted territories of the human experience, that the greatest rewards lie in wait.

In the wilderness of the human heart, a desolate cry echoes forth: "There is no God."  It is a refrain first inscribed in the dusty pages of Psalm 14, a testament to the unyielding skepticism that has long stalked the paths of men.  And so it is, too, with Thomas Aquinas, a voice crying out in the darkness, seeking to illuminate the shadows with the faint glow of reason.  St. Anselm, a precursor to this quest, stood before him, a beacon of faith that cast a different light upon the same desolate landscape.

To compare the arguments of these two men, we must first accept that they speak of the same God, the God of the Bible, a deity born of blood and fire, of sacrifice and redemption.  To conjure a false idol, a God of our own making, would be to betray the very purpose of their discourse.  And so, we must proceed with the understanding that their words are a testament to their shared conviction, a conviction that we shall dissect with the precision of a surgeon.

St. Anselm's argument is a labyrinth of introspection, a journey into the very depths of the human soul.  He posits that the existence of God is a truth that can be unearthed within the recesses of our own minds, a truth that cannot be diminished by the weight of empirical evidence.  It is a truth that arises from the dust of our own understanding, a spark that ignites within the darkness.  And so, he writes, we need not look beyond the boundaries of our own consciousness to find the proof of God, for it lies within the very fabric of our being.
